title: Tube commuters face major disruption as fresh industrial action to hit all Underground lines
text:
Wednesday 1 March 2017 07:16 GMT Click to followThe Evening Standard Tube commuters are facing yet more disruption Nigel Howard 
Tube commuters face ongoing daily disruption across all lines after union leaders ordered industrial action among up to 400 train fleet engineers. 
They will begin a work-to-rule from next Tuesday, 7 March, threatening delays to repairs and maintenance leading to trains having to be taken out of service. 
Delays are set to get progressively worse as the industrial action continues. 
The long-running dispute is over working conditions with the union claiming “abuse” of long-standing policies and procedures including those covering Night Tube. Tube Strike: 22nd February 2017 Tube Strike: 22nd February 2017 1/7 
Reduces service: a lone train running at Leytonstone Jeremy Selwyn 2/7 
Commuters walk to work today along The Thames embankment. The Waterloo and City line was closed Jeremy Selwyn 
Queues of commuters at Leytonstone Jeremy Selwyn 4/7 
There was further disruption as the Tube strike coincided with a strike by Southern Rail workers Jeremy Selwyn 
Passengers queue for replacement bus services at Leytonstone Jeremy Selwyn 
A large queue of commuters waiting for trains at Ilford Station ITV London 
Commuters queue at Ilford Station during the tube strike @MCR_Digital 
In a recent ballot 67 per cent of members voted for strike action with 88 per cent endorsing action short of a strike – with the RMT endorsing the latter. 
Mick Cash, the RMT leader, said: “The current level of flagrant abuse and ignorance of long-standing policies and procedures by London Underground (LU) is appalling and the anger among RMT Fleet grades members was clearly demonstrated in the ballot results. 
“The continued failures by the management side have left us with no option but to begin a campaign of industrial action.” 
He called on LU “to halt the bullying and harassment of our reps.” The union remained available “for serious talks.” 
Night Tube train drivers are to declare the result of their own strike ballot in a dispute over pay and jobs on Tuesday 14 March – union leaders forecast overwhelming support for the strike call. More about:
